readability_reflection:
In this survey, I found string interpolation to be significantly more readable. It just feels more intuitive to me to visually see where the variables are embedded in my string.

For example- print(f"Hello {name}, sup?")

Many editors like VS Code would highlight "{name}" in a different color, making it more intuitive to understand that it's a variable to be plugged in.
comprehension_debugging:
In string concatenation, it sometimes just takes you a second to gather your thoughts.

For example, when printing- 

"Water" + 4

I would need to run it and understand what will be printed, or if it will give me an error.

Whereas-

num = 4
"Water {num}"

This just feels right to the point. I have a variable that I want to plug after "Water"
preference_rationale: I would and have been using string interpolation for all my programming tasks, with a few minor exceptions here and there. As mentioned before, interpolation feels like a more solidified, grounded method.
learning_curve:
I have significant experience working in CS. I've worked on multiple projects, ranging from personal ones to production-ready ones for startups.

Recently, I've been working in inference engineering for Agentic LLMs, where I serve a system prompt with the tools embedded using string interpolation.
Example:

"""
You are a helpful assistant. Please use the following tools to help the user.
Tools:
{tools}

Tools description:
{tools_description}
"""
suggestions_improvement:
Having an IDE/editor highlight specifically what the variables are is really helpful.

For example, in VS Code working in Python, in my previous response, the "{tools}" and "{tools_description}" would be highlighted in blue and the rest of the string in orange.
